div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, February 18, 1942
div1.opener:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
February 18, 1942
Dear Dr Hench:
div1.p:
A letter from our distributors in Havana recently threw some
doubt on the professional standing of Dr. W H. Hoffman of the
Finlay Institute. Under separate cover you will receive a copy
of a letter received today.

Your letter of something over a week ago and the letter which
I received at home on Monday are both much appreciated. You
may be sure that you took care of all members of the family in
first class order. I saw Robin's letter before it was sent and
was particularly struck with the last sentence. We, of course,
don't edit her letters, but I was curious to know what she meant
that your coming year should not have “any holes” in it. Her
interpretation of that was that she hoped there would be no dark
spots or trouble. In other words, she sends you her best wishes
for the year. However, her use of the words “error” and “holes”
I thought were very funny going to a physician. Your note to her
and to Jonny gave them quite a lift to say the least. I have
spent a lot of time at Cornwell's in the last few weeks on the
McDowell painting.

We think we have arrived at a compromise which should please the
majority of physicians. It certainly will not be a painting
which is as suitable for the laity as that on “Yellow Fever”. We
called in the head of the Gynecology and Obstetrics Department of
one of the leading New York hospitals for advice as to the appear-
ance of tumor which we decided to show in the painting, and now
feel that from a technical standpoint the painting will be correct.

I am anticipating that one of our advisors, the wife of the Direct-
or of Public Health of Kentucky, Mrs. A.T. McCormick of Louisville,
is going to be permanently angry with us. I received a letter two
weeks ago after I had sent her a photograph of a sketch which was
almost blackmailed. She is editor of the “Quarterly Journal” repre-
senting the Medical Women's Auxiliary of the State. Her main in-
terest is in the patient, Jane Todd Crawford, but as Dr. Rankin
said very pointedly, “Thousands of patients, both men and women,
have given themselves into the hands of their doctors before the
McDowell operation, with possible outcomes as serious as that she
herself faced. The important thing was that McDowell performed
the ovariatomy and that it was successful. If Mrs. McCormick
proceeds to excoriate us for not making Mrs. Crawford the chief
person in the drama it will only serve to publicize the picture.
-2-
I gathered from her letter that Dr. Irwin Abell was closely assoc-
iated with her husband and that he sympathesizes with her point of
view. This disturbs me only insofar as I am afraid that Dr. Rankin
is going to be too busy to speak at an unveiling and Dr. Abell was
my second choice. If the whole thing blows up and we are not able
to get one or the other, Rankin or Abell, we will merely exhibit
the picture along with the other paintings at the A.M.A. at Atlantic
City and make no attempt to have any ceremony or unveiling. As war
conditions are today the newspapers will have very little space for
any paintings regardless of subject and I would rather spend the
money necessary for a bang-up occasion on reproductions of the
picture to send to the medical profession.

Thanks for the page from the catalogue giving an item concerning
Dorthea Lynde Dix. I shall order this at once even though we may
not do Miss Dix for two or three more years.

I don't think I have told you how extraordinarilly well Dr. Alvarez
treated me. He came through with a letter which may be of incal-
culable value to our associates, the Bisodol Company. I really
have to thank you for this.

I may be going to Seattle within the next few weeks and if I do so
I will attempt to stop in Rochester as I will be going by plane.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George A. Kellogg Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
